comments.content: Let's rehydrate our blobs from the lake

discussion.content: I can't believe someone said 'rehydrate' and thought 'yep, that's a good choice of words'.

Correct
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/storage/blobs/access-tiers-overview?tabs=azure-portal

Copilot: In Azure, when you store data in the Archive tier, it is considered “offline” and cannot be read or modified directly. To access this data, you need to rehydrate it to an online tier, such as the Hot or Cool tier. Here are the key points about data rehydration:

Rehydration Methods:
Copy Operation: You can copy the archived blob to a new blob in the Hot or Cool tier using the Copy Blob operation.
Change Tier: You can change the blob’s access tier directly from Archive to Hot or Cool using the Set Blob Tier operation12.
Rehydration Priority:
Standard Priority: This is the default option and can take up to 15 hours for objects under 10 GB.
High Priority: This option is faster, potentially completing in less than an hour for objects under 10 GB, but it costs more12.
Considerations:
Rehydrating large blobs is more efficient than rehydrating many small blobs.
You can monitor the rehydration status and adjust the priority if needed1.
Correct, same as Q115. Answer is "must be rehydrated before the data can be accessed."
Data Rehydration : https://www.komprise.com/glossary_terms/rehydration/

its in the exam - 17-April-2024

This is a repeat of question 125
Option 1: Nonsensical answer
Option 2: Also non-sense . What is the maximum session limit for a host pool?
The depth-first load balancing algorithm distributes sessions to session hosts up to the maximum session limit. If you use breadth-first when first creating a host pool, the default value for the maximum session limit is set to 999999 , which is also the highest possible number you can set this parameter to.
Option 3: A virtual desktop is a workstation existing in a virtual form that's separated from physical devices that use it. The virtual desktop provides a preconfigured view of operating systems and applications that can be accessed on different online devices through wifi connections.

Copilot: The number of simultaneous user connections in an Azure Virtual Desktop host pool depends on the configuration and the load balancing algorithm used.

Load Balancing Algorithms:
Breadth-first: Distributes user sessions evenly across all session hosts. This means each session host will have a roughly equal number of user sessions1.
Depth-first: Fills up one session host to its maximum capacity before moving on to the next1.
Session Limits:
The maximum number of sessions per host can be configured based on the VM size and the expected workload2. For example, a host might support 5 to 10 users depending on the resources allocated to it2.
In theory, you can set a very high maximum session limit, but practical limits depend on the performance and resource requirements of the applications being used3.
So, a host pool with 20 session hosts can support more than 20 simultaneous user connections, depending on how you configure the session limits and the load balancing strategy.
Answer is NNY. AVD support windows server operating system as well.

The answer to question Q1 is NO. Azure Virtual Desktop also supports Windows Server 2022, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2016. However, Windows 10 and Windows 11 are the only operating systems that support multi-session mode, which is the most commonly used mode for Azure Virtual Desktop. Therefore, the most accurate answer is no.

https://learn.microsoft.com/it-it/azure/virtual-desktop/prerequisites?tabs=portal#operating-systems-and-licenses

discussion.content: YYY is correct answer.

YYY
By definition: Virtual Machine Scale Sets (VMSS): A collection of identical VMs that are automatically managed and scaled together.
Azure Virtual Machine Scale Sets let you create and manage a group of load balanced VMs. 
The number of VM instances can automatically increase or decrease in response to demand or a defined schedule.

comments.content:
Easy to create and manage multiple VMs:
When you have many VMs that run your application, it's important to maintain a consistent configuration across your environment. For reliable performance of your application, the VM size, disk configuration, and application installs should match across all VMs.

discussion.content:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machine-scale-sets/overview

Allows your application to automatically scale as resource demand changes:
Customer demand for your application may change throughout the day or week. To match customer demand, scale sets can automatically increase the number of VM instances as application demand increases, then reduce the number of VM instances as demand decreases.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -

For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
NNN

GPT: in Azure, storage account names must be globally unique within Azure. This means that across all Azure subscriptions, no two storage accounts can have the same name. Each storage account name forms part of a unique URL, and this uniqueness requirement is enforced to ensure that the URL for each storage account is unique and can be resolved without ambiguity.

comments.content: Why? If its giving you the information you need why do you have a problem with it? If the community respects the answer then I have no problem with it. The fact someone went out to research it and posted it should means they are eager to learn and not just remember the answer. If you don't like Chatgpt then you have a long way to go in learning as its pretty much the future for now.

ChatGPT is actually right in this case: Storage account names actually need to be globally unique in all of Azure as per this article: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/troubleshooting/error-storage-account-name?tabs=bicep
“If you try to deploy a new storage account with the same name as a storage account that already exists in Azure. The existing storage account name might be in your subscription or tenant, or anywhere across Azure. Storage account names must be globally unique across Azure.”

discussion.content:
NNN
The bottom line is : Your storage account name must be unique within Azure. No two storage accounts can have the same name.
They must be globally unique across Azure. Storage account names can't be duplicated in Azure anywhere for the same company
GPT: in Azure, storage account names must be globally unique within Azure. This means that across all Azure subscriptions, no two storage accounts can have the same name. Each storage account name forms part of a unique URL, and this uniqueness requirement is enforced to ensure that the URL for each storage account is unique and can be resolved without ambiguity.
falsa verdadera verdadera
